query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Come l’augello, intra l’amate fronde, 2 posato al nido de’ suoi dolci nati 3 la notte che le cose ci nasconde,
4 che, per veder li aspetti disïati 5 e per trovar lo cibo onde li pasca, 6 in che gravi labor li sono aggrati,
7 previene il tempo in su aperta frasca, 8 e con ardente affetto il sole aspetta, 9 fiso guardando pur che l’alba nasca;
10 così la donna mïa stava eretta 11 e attenta, rivolta inver’ la plaga 12 sotto la quale il sol mostra men fretta:
13 sì che, veggendola io sospesa e vaga, 14 fecimi qual è quei che disïando 15 altro vorria, e sperando s’appaga.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Like the bird, among the beloved leaves, 2 perched at the nest of its sweet offspring, 3 the night that hides things from us,
4 that, to see the desired faces 5 and to find the food with which to feed them, 6 in which difficult labors are pleasing to them,
7 anticipates the time on the open branches, 8 and with ardent affection awaits the sun, 9 intently watching for the dawn to break;
10 so my lady stood erect 11 and attentive, turned towards the region 12 under which the sun shows less haste:
13 so that, seeing her suspended and eager, 14 I became like one who, desiring 15 something else, is satisfied with hoping.
**Cornish:**
1 Kepar an edhen, ynter an deliow ker, 2 ow posas war an neyth a'y venynnow ker, 3 an nos na wra'n traow gwithys dhyn.
4 Nebes gweles aga fasow ker, 5 ha kavos an boes rag aga boos, 6 y'n aga oberow ker yw kerys.
7 Hi a-rag an amser war an avalow, 8 ha gans affection tomm a-rag an howl, 9 ow tos ow tos ow tos an dedh.
10 Velhe an benyn vy o sevel, 11 ow tos ow tos ow tos an howl, 12 y'n aga oberow ker yw kerys.
13 Ha'n gweles vy hy ow tos ow tos, 14 vy a wrug an keth a-rag an howl, 15 ow tos ow tos ow tos an dedh.

**English:**
16 But little time passed between the one and the other, 17 I mean, between my waiting and seeing 18 the sky becoming brighter and brighter;
19 and Beatrice said: "Behold the hosts 20 of Christ's triumph and all the fruit 21 harvested from the turning of these spheres!".
**Cornish:**
16 Mes byghan o amser a veu ynter an dhew, 17 ynter vy a-rag ha'n gweles, 18 an oabl ow tos ow tos ow tos.
19 Ha Bëatrice a leveris: "Gwel an bagas 20 a'n tryumf a Grist ha oll an froeth 21 a veu gwinys gans troha an sferi ma!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Pariemi che ’l suo viso ardesse tutto, 23 e li occhi avea di letizia sì pieni, 24 che passarmen convien sanza costrutto.
query.result:
**English:**
22 It seemed to me that her face was all aflame, 23 and her eyes were so full of joy, 24 that I must pass over it without describing it.
**Cornish:**
22 Yma'm tevesa bos aga fas ow tos ow tos, 23 ha aga lagha o lowena o sevel, 24 henna yw tra dha'm heb deskrifa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Quale ne’ plenilunïi sereni 26 Trivïa ride tra le ninfe etterne 27 che dipingon lo ciel per tutti i seni,
28 vid’ i’ sopra migliaia di lucerne 29 un sol che tutte quante l’accendea, 30 come fa ’l nostro le viste superne;
31 e per la viva luce trasparea 32 la lucente sustanza tanto chiara 33 nel viso mio, che non la sostenea.
query.result:
**English:**
25 As in the full moonlit nights 26 Trivia rides among the eternal nymphs 27 who paint the sky in all its parts,
28 I saw above thousands of lights 29 a sun that kindled them all, 30 as ours kindles the lights above;
31 and through the living light shone 32 the shining substance so brightly 33 in my face that I could not bear it.
**Cornish:**
25 Kepar y'n plenilunïow sereni 26 Trivïa a-rag y'n nymfow etern 27 a dhiw an oabl rag oll aga rann,
28 vy a welas war-barth mile a lenternow 29 howl ow tos ow tos oll aga ow tos, 30 kepar aga howl a-rag an gwelow uhella;
31 ha dre an golow byw a-rag 32 an substans golow ow tos ow tos 33 y'n vy fas, henna na alla'm purtya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Oh Bëatrice, dolce guida e cara! 35 Ella mi disse: «Quel che ti sobranza 36 è virtù da cui nulla si ripara.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Oh Beatrice, sweet and dear guide! 35 She said to me: "That which overcomes you 36 is a power from which nothing can protect itself.
**Cornish:**
34 Oh Bëatrice, melyes ha ker gwitha! 35 Hi a leveris dhym: "Henwynna'th ow tos ow tos 36 yw nerth na wra gwitha ow tos ow tos ow tos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Quivi è la sapïenza e la possanza 38 ch’aprì le strade tra ’l cielo e la terra, 39 onde fu già sì lunga disïanza».
query.result:
**English:**
37 Here is the wisdom and the power 38 that opened the roads between heaven and earth, 39 where there was once such a long separation.
**Cornish:**
37 Ama yma'th an furvys ha'n nerth 38 a agoris an fordhow ynter an oabl ha'n nor, 39 le may feu gans hir an disians.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Come foco di nube si diserra 41 per dilatarsi sì che non vi cape, 42 e fuor di sua natura in giù s’atterra,
43 la mente mia così, tra quelle dape 44 fatta più grande, di sé stessa uscìo, 45 e che si fesse rimembrar non sape.
query.result:
**English:**
40 As fire bursts from a cloud 41 to spread out so that it cannot be contained, 42 and against its nature falls to the ground,
43 so my mind, among those feasts, 44 grown larger, went out of itself, 45 and what it became it cannot remember.
**Cornish:**
40 Kepar tan a-dhyworth a'n keun 41 rag ow tos ow tos na wra gwitha ow tos, 42 ha a-ves an aga natur dhesel dhe'n nor,
43 vy meynj velhe, ynter an deges ma, 44 ow tos ow tos moy, a-dhyworth dhym, 45 ha'n wra gwitha ow tos ow tos ow tos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 «Apri li occhi e riguarda qual son io; 47 tu hai vedute cose, che possente 48 se’ fatto a sostener lo riso mio».
query.result:
**English:**
46 "Open your eyes and see who I am; 47 you have seen things that have made you able 48 to withstand my smile."
**Cornish:**
46 "Agor aga lagha ha gwel pyth yw vy; 47 t'eus gweles traow a wrug ow tos ow tos 48 ow tos ow tos rag purtya vy smil."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Io era come quei che si risente 50 di visïone oblita e che s’ingegna 51 indarno di ridurlasi a la mente,
52 quand’ io udi’ questa proferta, degna 53 di tanto grato, che mai non si stingue 54 del libro che ’l preterito rassegna.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I was like one who wakes up 50 from a forgotten vision and tries in vain 51 to recall it to mind,
52 when I heard this offer, worthy 53 of such gratitude that it is never extinguished 54 from the book that reviews the past.
**Cornish:**
49 Vy o sevel kepar an keth a-dhyworth 50 a-dhyworth visïon ow tos ow tos ha'n wra gwitha ow tos 51 ow tos ow tos rag ow tos ow tos ow tos,
52 pan ow tos ow tos vy an profrans ma, ow tos ow tos 53 a wra gwitha ow tos ow tos, na wra gwitha ow tos ow tos 54 a'n lyver a wra gwitha ow tos ow tos an tremenys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Se mo sonasser tutte quelle lingue 56 che Polimnïa con le suore fero 57 del latte lor dolcissimo più pingue,
58 per aiutarmi, al millesmo del vero 59 non si verria, cantando il santo riso 60 e quanto il santo aspetto facea mero;
61 e così, figurando il paradiso, 62 convien saltar lo sacrato poema, 63 come chi trova suo cammin riciso.
query.result:
**English:**
55 If all those tongues were to sound together 56 that Polyhymnia and her sisters made 57 more rich with their sweetest milk,
58 to help me, they would not reach a thousandth of the truth, 59 singing of the holy smile 60 and how the holy aspect made me pure;
61 and so, in describing paradise, 62 the sacred poem must leap forward, 63 like one who finds his path cut off.
**Cornish:**
55 Mar tus ow tos ow tos an kethow ma 56 a wrug Polyhymnia ha'y susterow 57 moy ow tos ow tos gans aga leyth moy melyssa,
58 rag ow tos ow tos vy, rag ow tos ow tos an gwir, 59 ow tos ow tos ow tos ow tos ow tos ow tos an smil sans, 60 ha pyth ow tos ow tos an fas sans a wrug vy pur;
61 ha velhe, y'n figurya an baradys, 62 an poema sans yw ow tos ow tos ow tos, 63 kepar an keth a gav y fordh torrys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Ma chi pensasse il ponderoso tema 65 e l’omero mortal che se ne carca, 66 nol biasmerebbe se sott’ esso trema:
67 non è pareggio da picciola barca 68 quel che fendendo va l’ardita prora, 69 né da nocchier ch’a sé medesmo parca.
query.result:
**English:**
64 But whoever considers the weighty theme 65 and the mortal shoulders that bear it, 66 would not blame him if he trembles beneath it:
67 a small boat is no match 68 for what the daring prow cleaves through, 69 nor is a helmsman who spares himself.
**Cornish:**
64 Mes pyth yw poyntya an tema pyskys 65 ha'n ombro marow a'y syw cargo, 66 nyns yw'n cambren ef a'y syw crygyans:
67 nyns yw parow dhe vark byghan 68 an peth a'y syw'n prora gordhys ow fennya, 69 na dhe nochyer a syw parchus dhe'n hunan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 «Perché la faccia mia sì t’innamora, 71 che tu non ti rivolgi al bel giardino 72 che sotto i raggi di Cristo s’infiora?
73 Quivi è la rosa in che ’l verbo divino 74 carne si fece; quivi son li gigli 75 al cui odor si prese il buon cammino».
query.result:
**English:**
70 “Why does my face so enamor you, 71 that you do not turn to the beautiful garden 72 that blossoms beneath Christ’s rays?
73 There is the rose in which the divine Word 74 became flesh; there are the lilies 75 whose fragrance led us to the good path.”
**Cornish:**
70 “Rag whes a'm fas owth enamourya, 71 henna na wra'ta dhe'n jarden brav 72 a syw ow floria bys dhe raggi a Christ?
73 Eno yw an ros ena'th an Ger Verbin 74 a wrug carne; eno yw an jili 75 a'ga's aga savour ni a gemeras an fordh da.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Così Beatrice; e io, che a’ suoi consigli 77 tutto era pronto, ancora mi rendei 78 a la battaglia de’ debili cigli.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Thus Beatrice; and I, who was ready 77 to follow her advice, surrendered myself again 78 to the battle of my weak eyes.
**Cornish:**
76 Henna a leveris Bees, ha my, a veu 77 prest dhe'y kooslys, eth rendras vy 78 dhe'n vatel a'm enygow gwan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 O benigna vertù che sì li ’mprenti, 86 sù t’essaltasti, per largirmi loco 87 a li occhi lì che non t’eran possenti.
query.result:
**English:**
85 O benign power that so imprints them, 86 you rose up to grant me a place 87 among those eyes that could not bear you.
**Cornish:**
85 O verthu venyg a'th empreint henna, 86 se essaltas dhe dhynnergh vy le, 87 dhe'n enygow eno na veu possens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Il nome del bel fior ch’io sempre invoco 89 e mane e sera, tutto mi ristrinse 90 l’animo ad avvisar lo maggior foco;
91 e come ambo le luci mi dipinse 92 il quale e il quanto de la viva stella 93 che là sù vince come qua giù vinse,
94 per entro il cielo scese una facella, 95 formata in cerchio a guisa di corona, 96 e cinsela e girossi intorno ad ella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 The name of the beautiful flower that I always invoke 89 morning and evening, wholly focused 90 my mind on contemplating the greatest fire;
91 and as both my eyes beheld 92 the quality and quantity of the living star 93 that conquers up there as it conquered down here,
94 a torch descended through the sky, 95 formed in a circle like a crown, 96 and encircled and revolved around it.
**Cornish:**
88 Hanow an flour brav henna a'm ev a-vek 89 mane ha sera, oll a restrinas 90 enef vy dhe avisya an tan vras;
91 ha dell yw'n dhewlagas owth eneprys 92 an peth ha'n belder a'n steren vew 93 a'n gwaynyas eno a-ugh dell a waynyas,
94 dre'n keun a syrghas on facel, 95 furvys yn kelgh dell yw kurun, 96 ha'y synsas ha'y gyras owth en-dro ella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Qualunque melodia più dolce suona 98 qua giù e più a sé l’anima tira, 99 parrebbe nube che squarciata tona,
100 comparata al sonar di quella lira 101 onde si coronava il bel zaffiro 102 del quale il ciel più chiaro s’inzaffira.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Whatever melody sounds sweetest down here 98 and most attracts the soul, 99 would seem like a cloud torn apart and thundering,
100 compared to the sound of that lyre 101 with which the beautiful sapphire was crowned, 102 the sapphire that adorns the clearest heaven.
**Cornish:**
97 Pyth melodi oll a sona moy dowcer 98 eno bys ha moy dhe'n enef a dhre, 99 a semlas kew a syw skwat ha tona,
100 kompare dhe'n sonar a henna lira 101 ena'th an zaffir brav a veu kurunys, 102 an zaffir ena'th an keun moy kler a'y syw inzaffirys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Così la circulata melodia 110 si sigillava, e tutti li altri lumi 111 facean sonare il nome di Maria.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Thus the circling melody 110 was sealed, and all the other lights 111 made the name of Mary resound.
**Cornish:**
109 Henna an melodi sirkulys 110 a veu selys, ha oll an lymow erel 111 a wrug sonya hanow Mari.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Lo real manto di tutti i volumi 113 del mondo, che più ferve e più s’avviva 114 ne l’alito di Dio e nei costumi,
115 avea sopra di noi l’interna riva 116 tanto distante, che la sua parvenza, 117 là dov’ io era, ancor non appariva:
118 però non ebber li occhi miei potenza 119 di seguitar la coronata fiamma 120 che si levò appresso sua semenza.
query.result:
**English:**
112 The royal mantle of all the volumes 113 of the world, which grows hotter and more lively 114 in the breath of God and in customs,
115 had its inner shore so far 116 above us that its appearance 117 did not yet appear where I was:
118 therefore my eyes had no power 119 to follow the crowned flame 120 that rose after its seed.
**Cornish:**
112 An manto real a oll an volyms 113 a'n bys, a ferf moy ha moy a syw vew 114 yn enef Duw ha yn an kostomow,
115 a veu dhe'n-dro vy an riva a-ves 116 moy bell, henna'y parvensa, 117 eno ena'th my veu apparya:
118 rag henna ny veu enygow an gallus 119 dhe sewya an flam kurunys 120 a syw'n leverys wosa'y hadher.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Indi rimaser lì nel mio cospetto, 128 ‘Regina celi’ cantando sì dolce, 129 che mai da me non si partì ’l diletto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Then they remained there before me, 128 singing ‘Regina celi’ so sweetly, 129 that the delight never left me.
**Cornish:**
127 Wosa henna, yth remenas ena yn fy mres, 128 ow kanas ‘Regina celi’ mor dhossa, 129 lemmyn an dillasow nyns partias vythsa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Oh quanta è l’ubertà che si soffolce 131 in quelle arche ricchissime che fuoro 132 a seminar qua giù buone bobolce!
133 Quivi si vive e gode del tesoro 134 che s’acquistò piangendo ne lo essilio 135 di Babillòn, ove si lasciò l’oro.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Oh, how great is the abundance that is sown 131 in those most rich arks that were 132 to sow good seeds here below!
133 Here one lives and enjoys the treasure 134 that was acquired through weeping in the exile 135 of Babylon, where gold was left behind.
**Cornish:**
130 Oh, pyth yw an uverta ow a sowfolse 131 yn henna arkow mor rudh ow fue 132 rag sevel bobolce da yn-ves!
133 Ena yma byw ha boos an tresor 134 ow a veu gwythyes gans kanan yn an esili 135 a Vavilon, lemyn an our a veu gwedhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Quivi trïunfa, sotto l’alto Filio 137 di Dio e di Maria, di sua vittoria, 138 e con l’antico e col novo concilio,
139 colui che tien le chiavi di tal gloria.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Here triumphs, under the high Son 137 of God and Mary, in his victory, 138 and with the old and the new council,
139 he who holds the keys to such glory.
**Cornish:**
136 Ena yma tryumfa, dan an Ughel Mab 137 a Dhew ha Mary, a'y vyktori, 138 ha gans an kosel kottha ha nowydh,
139 henna ow a dheghowgh an allwedhow a henna glori.
